relax.translation[0].definitions[0].defi: to rest or do something that is enjoyable, especially after you have been working
relax.translation[0].definitions[0].exam: I just want to sit down and relax.
What Robyn needed was a drink to relax her.
A hot bath should help to relax you.
relax.translation[0].definitions[1].defi: to become quiet and calm after you have been upset or nervous, or to make someone do this
relax.translation[0].definitions[1].exam: Once out of danger, he started to relax.
relax.translation[0].definitions[2].defi: if you relax a part of your body or it relaxes, it becomes less stiff or less tight
relax.translation[0].definitions[2].exam: Gentle exercise can relax stiff shoulder muscles.
relax.translation[0].definitions[3].defi: to make a rule or law less strict
relax.translation[0].definitions[3].exam: Hughes believes that immigration controls should not be relaxed.
relax.translation[0].note_box[0].section: relax
to rest or do something that is enjoyable after you have been working
In the evenings, I like to relax with some music and a nice meal.
In two weeks’ time I’ll be relaxing on a beach in Greece.
rest
to stop working or stop being active, and sit down or lie down so that you become less tired
If you’re tired, we’ll stop and rest for a while.
The doctor told me to take some time off work and try to rest.
unwind
to gradually relax after you have been working hard or feeling anxious
It had been a bad day and he just wanted to get home and unwind.
Set in spectacular countryside, the Shiga Hotel is the perfect place to unwind.
take it/things easy
to relax and not do very much, especially after working very hard or being ill
Now that you’ve finished your exams, you can take it easy.
The doctor said he’ll have to take things easy for while.
put your feet up
to rest for a short time after a tiring activity, especially by sitting with your feet resting on something
Kate poured herself a drink and put her feet up.
When you’re pregnant and doing a full-time job, you must find time to put your feet up.
chill out/chill
to relax completely, or stop worrying and getting annoyed about things – used mainly by young people
We spent the day chilling out by the pool.
Hey dude, chill out! It’s only a car!
It’s a great place to chill out.
Let’s go back to my place and chill.
loosen up
to become more relaxed and stop worrying about things
I keep telling Mum that she needs to loosen up a bit.
Tom had had a few drinks and was beginning to loosen up.
put somebody at ease/make somebody feel at ease
to make someone feel relaxed, especially in a situation in which they might feel a little nervous
A good interviewer will try to make you feel at ease.
His friendly manner always puts people at their ease.
relax.translation[1].definitions[0].defi: to make rules etc less strict
relax.translation[1].definitions[0].exam: The country decided to relax its rules on the foreign ownership of its airlines.
Many employers are taking steps toward relaxed dress codes (=being allowed to dress informally at work) .
